user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Static(const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list  */
            break;
        }
        if (StaticSym->Module != NULL && strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0)
        {
            /* found matching module name */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
typedef const struct
{
    const char *Name;
    void (*Address)(void);
    const char *Module;
} OS_static_symbol_record_t
...
#define OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only use of a <string.h> function in this function is the strcmp call; there are no other calls to memcpy/memmove/memset/strcmp/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/strspn/etc. in the provided code. The rest of the function consists of simple declarations, a sentinel check (StaticSym->Name == NULL), and control-flow/return logic which do not themselves invoke or manipulate stdlib string functions and therefore do not directly create additional string-access risks beyond those related to the reported fragments. The provided typedef and macro definitions do not call any string functions either. Investigate the listed fragments to determine whether pointer parameters passed to the string function can ever be NULL or point outside the referenced object bounds (including cases where the static table sentinel may be missing or the caller provides a non-terminated or NULL ModuleName).
